I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Guangxi  Beibu  Gulf  Cities  Development 
Project.1 
 
2.  The project will improve basic urban infrastructure facilities and living condition of Beihai, 
Qinzhou, and Fangchenggang, three medium-sized seaport cities on the Beibu Gulf in the 
southern part of the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (Guangxi). Given their high growth 
potential and strategic location, the project will develop these cities to be engines of growth for 
Guangxi  and  gateways  for  the  country  to  its  Southeast  Asian  neighbors.  The  project  will 
incorporate  innovative  ideas  on  environmentally  friendly  and  climate-proof  technologies, 
universal  design,  and  transport  planning  for  enhancing  urban  safety.  These  new  urban 
approaches will be widely replicable within Guangxi and in the rest of the PRC.2 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Guangxi is one of 12 less-developed provinces and autonomous regions covered under 
the PRC’s Western Development Strategy.3 Guangxi shares a border of 1,020 kilometers (km) 
with Viet Nam and has 1,595 km of seacoast, which make Guangxi the only province that 
provides both seaport and land access for the neighboring landlocked provinces of Guizhou, 
Yunnan, and Hunan and farther west. Guangxi is emerging as an important national multimodal 
transport and trade gateway to link south and west parts of the PRC with neighboring countries 
in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). This can help Guangxi better contribute 
to achieving greater balance in the social and economic development of the PRC. 
  
4.  Although the growth in Guangxi’s gross domestic product (GDP) has exceeded the 
national average since 2001 due to support under the Western Development Strategy, GDP per 
capita in 2010 is only $2,791 and far below the national average of $4,394.4 Trade statistics 
show that the speed at which Guangxi is achieving growth from regional economic integration is 
not great enough. Guangxi is significantly less urbanized than the other provinces and its per 
capita rates of urban infrastructure investment and coverage are among the country’s lowest. 
The growth potential of Guangxi has been effectively constrained by the less developed urban 
infrastructure of the port cities along the Beibu gulf, which are endowed with deepwater harbors 
to serve as the national gateway for international trade and economic cooperation. 
 
5.  Together with the capital city of Nanning, the three project cities comprise the core part 
of  the  Guangxi  Beibu  Gulf  Economic  Development  Zone.5 Despite  national  and  provincial 
government  support,  they  are  struggling  to  expand  their  basic  urban  infrastructure  quickly

enough to improve poor living conditions and meet their growth targets. In Qinzhou and Beihai, 
limited  road  networks  and  the  poor  quality  of  existing  roads  result  in  fragmented  urban 
expansion  and  low  quality  of  life  for  residents.  Inefficient  transport  connections  between 
residential areas and port industrial zones also make industrial operations difficult in these 
cities. In Fangchenggang, inadequate existing road capacity and poor traffic safety cannot 
support  basic  living  conditions  for  the  increasing  urban  population  and  growing  logistics 
activities  with  the  border  city  of  Dongxing.  Untreated  municipal  and  industrial  wastewater 
degrades the urban environment and increases public health risks. The lack of a centralized 
wastewater  treatment  plant  (WWTP)  is  also  a  bottleneck  for  industrial  development  in 
Fangchenggang. All of these lead to (i) deterioration in the quality of life especially for the poor, 
(ii)  limited  investment  prospects  in  the  three  project  cities,  and  (iii)  delay  in  promoting 
international and national regional economic integration for Guangxi.6 
 
6.  The  project  will  help  these  three  cities  (i) promote  environmentally  sound  urban 
development; (ii) improve quality of life by providing access to better social services and a 
cleaner environment to the poor; (iii) improve the investment climate, as well as international 
and domestic trade and commerce; and (iv) accelerate sustainable socioeconomic development 
and  poverty  reduction  through  increased  employment  opportunities  for  the  poor  and  rural 
migrants. Improved road access and transport facilities will connect key urban districts and port 
industrial areas, and contribute to better ambient air quality and fuel efficiency. A WWTP will 
alleviate environmental pollution of surface water and reduce health hazards. The project design 
incorporates lessons from past Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed projects in the PRC to 
ensure financial viability of the wastewater facility, close institutional coordination for timely 
sewer network construction, enhanced road safety, and sustainable operation and maintenance 
(O&M) of project facilities.7  
 
7.  The project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 that is now 
under preparation and that will continue to highlight sustainable urban development with low 
environmental impacts. This will also be the focus of the government's Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 
2011–2015. The PRC’s national and regional strategies for growth prioritize urban infrastructure 
and  environmental  sustainability.  The  project  is  also  consistent  with  ADB's  urban  sector 
strategy, water policy, and strategic priorities on climate change,8 and will help the PRC work to 
achieve Millennium Development Goal 7, Target 7.C.9 The project will demonstrate special 
features for potential replication in other cities in the PRC: 
(i)  Environmentally  friendly  technologies.  The  choice  of  technology  for  the 
project has been driven by medium- and long-term environmental, social, and 
economic benefits. The project roads will be the first in Guangxi to use public 
utility  conduits  for  underground  urban  infrastructure  to  avoid  unnecessary 
environmental impact from O&M.10 Energy-efficient street lighting and signage 
will also support low-carbon city development. The WWTP will use advanced

(ii)  Climate  proofing  of  urban  districts  and  infrastructure. The three coastal 
cities are vulnerable to future climate change impacts. The technical design of 
the project roads includes such climate-proofing measures as slope protection 
and erosion control and permeable surfacing for sidewalks for a sustainable 
urban drainage system. A study on design guidelines for climate proofing will also 
be prepared under the capacity development component. 
(iii)  Universal design for urban infrastructure and public facilities.11  The project 
will strengthen the cities’ capacity to adopt the concept of universal design in 
planning urban infrastructure. This will enable them to raise livability standards 
and better meet the needs of elderly and vulnerable people. The basic design will 
be  considered  during  the  detailed  design  and  a  separate  study  will  be 
implemented under the project to enhance design concept and planning policy. 
(iv)  Human-centered  planning  of  urban  districts  transport.  The  project  will 
provide  capacity  development  training  to  promote  urban  safety  and  human-
centered  district  and  transport  planning,  including  advanced  urban  transport 
planning for  emergency  response  and  inclusive  district  land  use  planning to 
benefit the poor and rural migrants. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be improved basic living conditions and socioeconomic development in 
the three port cities to support the PRC’s regional cooperation. The outcome will be better urban 
infrastructure services and environment in the three project cities. 
 
C.  Outputs 
9.  The project will generate outputs from five investment components and one capacity 
development and institutional strengthening component:  
(i)  Beihai Zhulin urban road and related infrastructure. Outputs will be 8.4 km of 
urban road and related infrastructure, including 16.8 km of storm water drainage 
pipelines, sewerage pipelines, street lighting and signage, and landscaping; 
(ii)  Beihai Yingpan road and related infrastructure. Outputs will be 7.8 km of 
urban road with a 650-meter bridge and related infrastructure, including 13.1 km 
of storm water drainage pipelines, 13.2 km of water supply pipelines, 4.5 km of 
sewerage pipelines, street lighting and signage, and landscaping; 
(iii)  Qinzhou  Port  Xincheng  urban  road  network  and  related  infrastructure. 
Outputs  comprise  12.2 km  of  urban  road  network  and  related  infrastructure, 
including  21.1  km  of  sewerage  pipelines,  33.3  km  of  storm  water  drainage 
pipelines, 12.2 km of public utility conduits, street lighting and signage, and 
landscaping; 
(iv)  Fangchenggang  Fangcheng–Jiangshan  road  and  related  infrastructure. 
Outputs comprise 16.1 km of urban road and related infrastructure, including 
32.3 km of storm water drainage ditches, traffic signage and landscaping; 
(v)  Fangchenggang Maoling wastewater treatment plant and sewerage network. 
Outputs will be a WWTP with a capacity of 30,000 cubic meters per day, with 24

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
14.  The project will pose little technical risk. Engineering designs with records of proven 
reliable performance will be adopted for construction of roads and bridge, the WWTP, and 
related municipal infrastructure. Technical feasibility was found to be adequate after careful 
examination of the project’s compatibility with local conditions and future demand projections for 
road traffic and wastewater generation. Different technical options were analyzed to identify the 
best routes  and  plant  location, road materials,  bridge  design,  and  wastewater  and  sludge 
treatment process. The project engineering designs will adopt advanced technologies, such as 
energy-saving  street  lighting,  public  utility  conduits,  and  a  treatment  process  capable  of 
removing more nitrogen and phosphorous from wastewater. Technical due diligence analysis 
revealed little technical risk in having these components locally constructed and operated. The 
project will provide training under its capacity development component to ensure sustainable 
O&M of project facilities. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
15.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was estimated by comparing with- and 
without-project  scenarios.  The  project’s  economic  costs  reflect  (i)  the  capital  cost  for 
construction, including physical contingencies, land acquisition, resettlement and environmental 
monitoring costs; and (ii) O&M costs, which include routine annual maintenance and periodic 
major maintenance. The economic benefits of the road components are savings in (i) vehicle 
operating costs, (ii) travel time for road users, and (iii) road accident costs—the result of fewer 
accidents. Quantifiable economic benefits of the Maoling WWTP component are focused on 
health benefits. The EIRRs for the project’s five components ranged from 12.7% to 23.7%. The 
net present value for the whole project is CNY1,391.8 million and the EIRR is 18.7%. Sensitivity

7 
analysis shows that the EIRRs for a 20% reduction in benefits, a 20% increase in capital cost, a 
1-year project completion delay, and the combination of these three cases are 16.0%, 16.6%, 
18.6%, and 13.8% respectively. This indicates that the project is economically viable.15 
 
16.  The financial viability of the revenue-generating Maoling WWTP component indicates 
that the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) is 5.2%, which exceeds the weighted average 
cost of capital (WACC) of 2.4%. Sensitivity analysis of the FIRR shows that the project remains 
financially robust in the face of adverse changes including capital cost increases, demand 
decreases, operating cost increases, and a 1-year delay in project completion. Wastewater 
tariffs will need to be increased every 5 years after the ADB-financed facilities commence 
operation.  The  analysis  concluded  that  low-income  households  will  be  able  to  afford  the 
projected tariff increases since the share of income expended on water and wastewater will be 
around  0.6%  of  household  income  per month  which  is  well  below  the  benchmark  of  5%. 
Lessons from past urban sector projects generated recommendations for detailed financial 
analysis of potential delays in water and wastewater tariff increases. The financial sustainability 
of the Maoling WWTP was also supported by the analysis that its FIRR would remain higher 
than the WACC (2.4%) if the proposed tariff increase is implemented every 10 years instead of 
every 5 years. The FIRR drops to 2.5%, in the case of a combination of (i) a 10% increase in 
capital costs, (ii) a 10% decrease in demand, and (iii) a 10% increase in operating costs. The 
Fangchenggang  municipal  government  has  committed  to  provide  subsidies  to  sustain  the 
operation if revenues do not cover O&M costs. For nonrevenue road components, the financial 
analysis indicated that the three cities present acceptable levels of fiscal risk in their abilities to 
provide counterpart funds, service project debt, and fund the O&M of the project components. 
The highest percentage of the cities’ municipal fiscal revenues that would be required for such 
funding  annually  ranges  from  0.65%  to  1.28%  over  the  project  period  (2011–2016).  The 
maximum projected debt service requirements for the three cities will be about 0.03% to 0.06% 
of their projected annual revenues during the project operation period.16 
 
C.  Governance 
17.  The project will be ADB’s ninth loan to Guangxi, which is also successfully managing 
other multisector urban development projects funded by other bilateral and multilateral financial 
institutions. The financial management and procurement capacity assessments concluded that 
GZARG, the municipal governments, and the project implementing companies (PICs) have 
adequate capacity for financial management and procurement in accordance with ADB policies 
and procedural requirements, and national procurement laws and regulations. Under GZARG 
supervision, the municipal governments and the PICs are also receiving support and knowledge 
on  governance  issues  from  the  project  cities  of  ADB’s  Guangxi  Southwestern  Cities 
Development  Project.17 They  and  GZARG  will  also  benefit from  the capacity  development 
programs and governance activities under ADB’s technical assistance for Capacity Building for 
Enhanced Partnership and Development Impact.18 The project’s technical support provides a 
further opportunity for the PICs to strengthen their internal audit system through training. ADB’s 
Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with GZARG, 
the municipal governments, and their project management offices. Specific policy requirements 
and supplementary measures are described in the PAM. 
                                                
15  Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
16  Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
17 ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the 
People’s Republic of China for the Guangxi Southwestern Cities Development Project. Manila (Loan 2657-PRC). 
18 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Capacity Building for Enhanced Partnership 
and Development Impact. Manila (TA 7703-PRC).

8 
D.  Poverty and Social 
18.  An  estimated  651,900  people  will  benefit  directly  from  the  project.  The  project 
construction  phase  will  create  9,850  person-years  of  direct  employment  opportunities  and 
another 25,610 person-years indirectly, generating an estimated CNY240.36 million in earnings 
for the direct beneficiaries and CNY624.94 million for those who benefit indirectly. Direct jobs 
during the project operation phase will total 1,190, indirect jobs, 3,090. They will generate 
estimated earnings of CNY26.89 million and CNY69.83 million, respectively. GZARG and the 
municipal governments have committed to prioritizing the employment of vulnerable groups, 
including the poor, women, and ethnic minorities. To reinforce the positive benefits of improved 
transport and wastewater treatment, municipal governments will conduct public programs on 
road safety and environmental awareness during the project. These programs will address the 
needs of and risks to women and children presented by increased traffic and environmental 
degradation. The social action plan will be supervised and monitored by resettlement and social 
development specialists under the project management consulting services.19 
 
19.  Gender benefits. The project is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming. Results 
from the household survey and focus group discussions indicate that the primary responsibilities 
of women in the project-influenced area are household-related travel, housekeeping activities, 
and taking care of sick and old family members. The project will reduce travel time burdens on 
women and improve their mobility and access. Women in all project areas strongly support the 
project and expect it to improve their quality of life and to create employment and income 
opportunities. The project includes a gender action plan to help ensure (i) increased women’s 
participation  in the  project,  including  a target of  at  least  20%  employment for  women; (ii) 
women’s  participation  in gender-sensitive training  on  public road  safety  and environmental 
awareness programs; and (iii) the setting and tracking of gender targets, indicators, and sex-
disaggregated  data  for  project  monitoring  and  evaluation. 20  Resettlement  and  social 
development  specialists  in the  project management  consulting  service  will  ensure  that  the 
gender action plan is implemented and monitored. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
20.  Environment. The project is classified under environmental category A. Environmental 
impact assessments (EIAs) were prepared for each of the five investment components and 
reviewed and approved by the respective environmental protection bureau. GZARG disclosed 
relevant environment information to environmentally affected people through consultations in 
April–October 2010 and the results and findings were reflected in the EIAs and the project 
design. A project EIA, including an environmental management plan (EMP) and environmental 
monitoring  program,  assesses  the  potential  adverse  environmental  impacts  of  urban  road 
networks and the WWTP during construction and operation of project facilities.21 The main 
identified environmental impacts relate to air, water and noise pollution, solid waste disposal, 
and borrow and spoil management during project construction. The EMP fully addresses these 
impacts as well as occupational health and safety issues to ensure residual environmental 
impacts are insignificant. In addition to addressing common environmental protection issues, the 
project also demonstrates good environmental due diligence practice by pursuing measures to 
enhance  environmental  management  on  an  existing  nature  reserve.  The  municipal 
environmental  protection  bureaus  will  support  the  municipal  governments  and  the  PICs  in 
                                                
19 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
20 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
21 Environmental Impact Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
implementing the EMPs. Capacity building in environmental management will be provided for 
GZARG, the municipal governments, and the PICs. An environmental monitoring report will be 
prepared by GZARG and submitted to ADB semiannually during implementation and annually 
for 2 years after project completion. A grievance redress mechanism was established under 
GZARG, the municipal governments, and the PICs to receive and redress public grievances 
related to environment. The EIA was circulated to the ADB Board of Directors and made publicly 
available through the ADB website on 10 December 2010. 
 
21.  Involuntary  resettlement.  The  project  is  classified  under  involuntary  resettlement 
safeguard category A.22 Five resettlement plans were approved by ADB on 7 January 2011, 
disclosed to affected persons, and uploaded to the ADB website on 25 January 2011.23 Overall, 
the project will acquire 5,288.55 mu of land permanently, of which 30.36% is classified as 
farmland.24 Permanent land acquisition will affect 4,555 persons. Temporary acquisition of 469 
mu of land will affect 3,173 persons. A total of 1,045 persons will be relocated and about 34,804 
square  meters  of  residential  and  non-residential  buildings  will  be  demolished.  Removal  of 
546.62 mu of shrimp aquaculture ponds will affect the livelihoods of 155 persons. In addition, 
associated productive assets, ground attachments, and basic infrastructure facilities will also be 
affected. The levels of compensation are based on the relevant PRC regulations, which were 
confirmed to be adequate after consultation with local governments and those affected, and 
considering  general  practice  in  project  cities.  The  implementation  of  the  project’s  five 
resettlement plans will be monitored and evaluated internally and externally. The municipal 
governments  will  report  implementation  progress  regularly  to  GZARG,  which  in  turn  will 
summarize the land acquisition and resettlement progress in the quarterly progress report to 
ADB. The Guangxi project management office will also engage an independent external monitor 
who will (i) review resettlement progress and the general welfare of affected persons, (ii) make 
recommendations to resolve any issues or problems, and (iii) provide advice to GZARG and the 
municipal governments. The external monitor will pay special attention to vulnerable groups, 
including the poor, women, and the ethnic minorities, to assess whether they have fully regained 
their standard of living. Monitoring and evaluation reports will be prepared semiannually during 
implementation and annually for 2 years after resettlement is completed. They will be submitted 
to  ADB  and  published  on  ADB’s  website.  The  project  has  also  established  a  transparent 
grievance channel that will (i) provide a meaningful consultation mechanism and (ii) trigger 
remedial action by GZARG and the municipal governments. 
 
22.  Indigenous  peoples.  The  project  is  classified  under  indigenous  people  safeguard 
category C. Ethnic minorities, predominantly from the Zhuang ethnic group, make up 23.7% of 
the urban population. The poverty and social assessment survey and consultations concluded 
that all urban beneficiaries, including ethnic minorities in the project areas, will benefit from the 
infrastructure improvements. There will be no adverse impacts other than resettlement for 13 
ethnic  minority  households.  This  will  be  addressed  under  the  resettlement  plan  for  the 
Fangchenggang Fangcheng–Jiangshan road and related infrastructure component. The overall 
project design includes prioritization of ethnic minorities for construction jobs and O&M activities 
and  the  use  of  the  local  language,  where  necessary,  in  communication  and  outreach  for 
involuntary resettlement consultations. 
                                                
22 Resettlement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
23 ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) adjusted the terminology for involuntary resettlement, changing "affected  
persons" to "displaced persons," who were defined as persons physically and/or economically displaced due to 
involuntary acquisition of land or involuntary restrictions on land use or on access to legally designated parks and 
protected areas. Although resettlement plans for ADB projects in the PRC maintain the original terminology of 
“affected persons,” this is equivalent to the new Safeguard Policy Statement definition of “displaced persons.” 
24 A mu is a Chinese unit of measurement (1 mu = 666.667 square meters).

10 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
23.  The  overall  risk  assessment  was  reduced  to  low  through  the  formulation  of  risk 
management measures to be implemented prior, during, and after project implementation. Major 
risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in the risk 
assessment and risk management plan.25 The project’s integrated benefits and impacts are 
expected to outweigh costs and risks.

IV.  ASSURANCES  
24.  The national government and GZARG have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
25.  The national government and GZARG have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for 
the project, which are set forth in the loan agreement and project agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
26.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
$200,000,000 to the People’s Republic of China for the Guangxi Beibu Gulf Cities Development 
Project from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, 
including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board. 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President
